data.title: [regression] config changes not applied
data.body:
- Open VS Code with a single editor group
- Open Settings
- Change any editor setting (font size, family, etc)
- Go to left editor (read only)
- Quick open _any_ file

The settings that were changed will not be applied in that new file.

data.title: Errors aren't cleared when isWatching is true
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X, 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Define a command in tasks.json to use with "isWatching" : true and a custom problemMatcher.
2. Problem matcher will report errors but those errors won't get cleared if fixed / on auto-recompile.

If I remove the isWatching, everything works properly.

data.title: Completions for $schema only work if string empty
data.body:
- VSCode Version: insiders latest
- OS Version: os x

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a `myjson.json` with the following content
2. Trigger intelisense after character 'h' - notice you do not get any useful proposals
3. Delete 'h' and trigger intelisense again - notice all the proposals start with 'h'

``` json
{
"$schema": "h|trigger intelisense here"
}
```

data.title: Duplicate function implementation error message while writing simple function
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7
  Steps to reproduce: 
- Write one simple function
- Notice the red underline
  Error message : Duplicate function implementation.

Same happens for all the variables I declare using `let` keyword.
What am I doing wrong. I have tried examples from http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/variable-declarations.html but they also show same error.

data.title: Menus do not align with High Contrast

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Switch to High Contrast theme in Windows
2. Open VSCode and check any menu (File, Edit, View, ...)

The menu item text is not visible as shown below
![invisible-menu-text-highcontrast-win](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20694372/17199691/6383868c-549c-11e6-9712-ab5ac1e94aa5.png)

However hovering the mouse over a menu item will make the text visible since the selection background is blue. The key bindings are also visible without mouse hover since the text color is gray.
The menu decoration should consider aligning the background and text color with High Contrast settings.

data.title: Jsconfig.json hint logic
data.body:
The green lightbulb in the bottom of VS Code is very convenient for generating jsconfig.json. The problem is it doesn't show up all the time. In fact, when does it show up? 

Here is what I have done to try to make it give me the hint. 
1. Delete jsconfig.json
2. Reload Window
3. Restart VS Code

I can't seem to get it to come back. 

My feature request is that we change the logic so the hint shows up each time jsconfig.json should be there and it isn't (with an option to ignore the hint). 

Secondly, we should make it possible to invoke the action the hint suggests through the command palette.

data.title: Have a setting for maximum number open files (editors)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I've noticed that there is no way to limit the number of total files open at once. There is an `explorer.openEditors.visible` option, but that seems to limit the height of the "Open Editors" pane (which I don't use - I use tabs instead).

To keep my workspace focused, I like my editor to automatically close files over a set threshold that I have least recently viewed. Obviously, it wouldn't close files that have unsaved changes (or it would prompt you prior to trying to close them).

Does this sound like a reasonable request? Please let me know!

data.title: PR Proposal: Open arbitrary commits with diff viewer
data.body:
I would like to add a feature to VS Code in order to address a gap in my usage of it. I figured I should writeup my idea before submitting a pull request in order to get feedback from the VS Code team and maximize the chances that my PR will be along the lines of something the team will be interested in accepting.
### Motivation

VS Code has a fantastic diff viewer. It let's you see a list of changed files and, when you click on a file, it shows you the entire file and what changed in it. However, it is limited to seeing changes in your index and working tree. I'd like to extend the diff viewer so that it can be used to view the changes included in arbitrary commits.

This cannot be done as an extension because extensions cannot render into the side pane where the diff viewer displays the list of changed files.

In my workflow, I interact with git through the command line and through VS Code. Viewing diffs is one thing that VS Code can do much better than the command line so I'd like to see this feature in VS Code.
### Proposal

VS Code currently has a few side panes and one of them is for interacting with git. I propose extending it to support multiple views. The functionality that VS Code ships with today will be called the "Status" view. It shows you the changes in your index and working tree. The only change is that there will be a dropdown at the top of the pane for switching between views:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199935/17192989/d7876aae-5405-11e6-9898-27c5e2d718e4.png)

There will be another option in the dropdown called "History". This represents a new view which enables you to view the changes in a particular commit. This is what it will look like:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199935/17193126/6f417772-5406-11e6-84f9-cff2ee4a1517.png)

It will have two input fields. If you want to see the changes in a particular commit, you can enter the commit name into the first field. As you would expect, you can click on a changed file to view its diff:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199935/17193009/ec9cd136-5405-11e6-83fe-21b89ceb6200.png)

If you want to view all of the changes in a range of commits, you can leverage the second field. For example, here I'm viewing all of the changes that occurred between my feature branch, `rigdern/diff`, and `master`:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199935/17193015/f11ebdb4-5405-11e6-8bfc-954e60931214.png)

You may be wondering how developers will find the names of the commits to put into the two input fields. I've thought of a couple of options:
1. One option is that they'll get them from an external tool. For example, in my case I'll get them from running `git log` on the command line. As I alluded to earlier, the command line works fine for browsing commit messages but it's not very good for looking at diffs.
2. Another option is through a VS Code extension. We could expose an extension API enabling extensions to set the commit that the new git "History" view is displaying. Then a developer could write an extension which provides the functionality of `git log` within VS Code. It could interact with the new git "History" view when the user clicks on a commit in the log.

VS Code Team, what do you think of this proposal? I'd like to get some feedback on it and, if this is a feature you'd be interested in having, I'm interested in working on a pull request.

data.title: First tab not rendering right.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.3

Normal tabs must be rendered as:

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2157285/17191281/806877a0-545e-11e6-98ed-87fa4153444d.png)

With 2 borders at right and left. However the first tab always renders like this:

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2157285/17191307/a29d5dae-545e-11e6-8568-b69cabb25e4d.png)

If you notice, in the left side of the tab has a bad rendering. In the dark it's really fine but in the light it renders bad. I suggest having a border or something around there...

As always.
I hope you're doing great and thanks for the awesome editor.
Pouya
